data.context:
To Whom It May Concern, I am writing to report a significant and deeply concerning breach of my personal data related to my student loan records. It has come to my attention that my federally protected personal information was accessed by, shared with, or otherwise disclosed to XXXX XXXX or entities under his control, without my consent or knowledge.

This unauthorized access violates multiple federal laws and protections : The Privacy Act of 1974 ( 5 U.S.C. 552a ) This law prohibits federal agencies from disclosing personal information without written consent, except under specific, lawful exceptions. My student loan informationmaintained by the U.S. Department of Education or its servicersshould have been safeguarded under this law. Any unauthorized sharing of my data constitutes a direct violation.

The Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ) ( 20 U.S.C. 1232g ) FERPA protects the privacy of student education records and prohibits disclosure without student consent, including financial aid and loan data when administered by educational institutions or federal programs. This breach appears to contravene FERPAs strict data handling policies.

The Federal Trade Commission Act ( 15 U.S.C. 4158 ) Under Section 5, the FTC prohibits unfair or deceptive acts or practices, including those involving misuse or unauthorized disclosure of consumer data. The disclosure of my private loan information without permission, especially to a non-governmental individual or company, may be an unfair practice and subject to FTC enforcement.

Department of Education Data Governance and Sharing Regulations Under federal student aid regulations, third-party access to loan data must be strictly controlled and logged. Unless expressly authorized or contractually bound to the Department of Education, no external entityespecially not a private corporate actor such as XXXX XXXXshould

be permitted access to my loan or personal records. This disclosure indicates a failure in oversight or a breach of the Departments regulatory framework.

Given the seriousness of these violations, I am requesting the following actions : A formal investigation into how my information was accessed, who authorized it, and for what purpose.

Immediate remedial action to secure and restrict further access to my personal data.

Written confirmation of how my rights were violated under the laws listed above.

Consideration of full loan cancellation or discharge, as restitution for the breach, loss of trust, and potential harm to my identity and financial wellbeing.

I have also submitted complaints to the Federal Student Aid Feedback Center, the Federal Trade Commission, and the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau. I reserve the right to pursue further legal or civil remedies should this matter not be addressed promptly and appropriately.

Please confirm receipt of this complaint and advise me of the steps your office will take in response. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX

data.context:
I am filing a complaint regarding improper handling of my federal student loans by Nelnet, particularly related to lack of required notification and premature delinquency reporting. 

On XX/XX/XXXX, Nelnet sent me a letter through their portal stating that my federal loans with 0 % interest were paused as of XX/XX/XXXX, through when the payment pause would end, under COVID-19 relief measures and explicitly said : We will notify you in advance of when these relief measures will end. However, I never received any communication from Nelnet notifying me that repayment was restarting, or when my first bill would be due. 

The first indication I received that my loans had entered repayment came in a letter from their portal dated XX/XX/XXXX, stating I was already 15 days past due. I received another notice from their portal on XX/XX/XXXX with the same message, stating that I was again 15 days past due. Then, on XX/XX/XXXX, I received a letter from their portal saying I was 45 days past due. Again, none of these letters came with prior billing statements or warnings about due dates. I never received a statement showing a payment schedule, amount due, or that the CARES Act pause had officially ended. 

In XX/XX/XXXX, my credit score dropped XXXX  XXXX  due to Nelnet reporting my loans as 90120 days past due. These delinquencies were reported without ever having given me proper notice that repayment had resumed, contrary to their own written commitment on XX/XX/XXXX and to Department of Education guidelines. 

I am requesting that the CFPB investigate Nelnet for failure to : -Properly notify me that my loans were exiting forbearance and entering repayment -Provide billing statements or reminders prior to delinquency -Accurately report delinquencies in accordance with the Fair Credit Reporting Act

The new payment amount will nearly double the payment from $180.00 per month to $360.00 per month.
The customer is fortunate that the current financial position allows handling the increased payment amount.
There are likely many borrowers who are not in the same financial position.
The re-amortization should have occurred once the forbearance ended.
The re-amortization would reduce the impact to borrowers.

The first segment highlights that credit bureaus are still reporting student loans that are now unverified and potentially void due to the dissolution of the Department of Education, constituting violations of the Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA) and the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act (FDCPA). The second segment further explains that unauthorized access to borrower data and continued reporting of accounts under the 'DEPT OF EDUCATION/NELN' tradeline violate federal privacy laws like the Privacy Act of 1974, FERPA, and the Higher Education Act. It also states that the contractual obligations of the Department of Education and its agents have been breached, rendering the associated debt and reporting invalid. Consumer rights advocates argue that these actions constitute illegal credit reporting, breach of privacy statutes, and violations of federal laws, demanding immediate investigation, deletion of accounts, and cessation of collection efforts.

data.context: I initially had XXXX as my student loan provider but decided to consolidate my loans and chose AidVantage as the provider. The loans were accepted and dispersed to AidVantage in XX/XX/year> with first payment due on XX/XX/year>. I set up my account and included my banking info to make electronic transfer of funds payments and made the first payment on XX/XX/XXXX. A few days later I received notice that the payment was reversed. I logged into my AidVantage account and checked to make sure my routing and account number were correct. They were, so I attempted to make the payment again on XX/XX/XXXX. They were AidVantage system added both the XX/XX/XXXX payment and the XXXX fifth payment together, doubling the payment amount but I continued to process the payment. Again, a few days later the payment was reversed. I contacted AidVantage through the website and received the response to check to make sure the banking information I entered was correct ( which I had already done ) and to contact my bank to see if they were not accepting the transfer, which ai havent been able to do yet. Im not the average student loan borrower as I am almost XXXX XXXX XXXX, but there has to be a better way to simply make a loan payment. Any assistance appreciated.

inputs.user_input: How does the violation of the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA) relate to the improper use of my student loan report and the breach of my personal info?
inputs.response:
The violation of the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA) is directly related to the improper use of your student loan report and the breach of your personal information. FERPA is a federal law that mandates the protection and confidentiality of students' educational records and personally identifiable information (PII). When this law is violated, it means that your educational records or PII have been accessed, disclosed, or handled without proper authorization or your consent.

In the context of your complaints, the improper use of your student loan report and the breach of your personal info are considered violations of FERPA because they involve unauthorized disclosures or mishandling of your private educational and financial data. Such breaches can lead to unauthorized transactions, identity theft, or fraud, and undermine your rights to privacy and data security.

Therefore, FERPA violations relate to these issues by indicating that your rights to confidentiality and proper data handling were not upheld, resulting in the exposure and misuse of your personal and loan-related information.

Complaint Details : 1. Illegal Credit Reporting The credit bureaus continue to report student loans that are now unverified and legally questionable due to the dissolution of the Department of Education.

2. Failure to Verify Legitimacy of Debt The loan servicer ( DEPTEDNELNET ) has failed to provide evidence of legal ownership, collection rights, or servicing obligations in light of the agencys abolishment.

3. Unfair and Deceptive Practices The continued collection of these debts constitutes a violation of my rights under the FCRA ( 15 U.S.C. 1681 ) and FDCPA ( 15 U.S.C. 1692 ). 

I demand an immediate investigation, deletion of these accounts from my credit report, and cessation of any collection efforts by my loan servicer. If this matter is not resolved promptly, I will pursue further legal action. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX

retrieved_contexts:
To Whom It May Concern, I am writing to formally dispute my student loan account due to a violation of the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ) and a breach of my personal data. I recently became aware of unauthorized disclosures of my personally identifiable information ( PII ), which directly impact my loan account and my financial security. 

Under FERPA ( 20 U.S.C. 1232g ; 34 CFR Part 99 ), my educational records and personal data should have been protected from unauthorized access and disclosure. However, I have reason to believe that my information was improperly handled, which may have led to unauthorized transactions, fraudulent activity, or mismanagement of my loan account. 

Additionally, I have been notified of a potential data breach involving my student loan information, which has put my financial identity at risk. This breach is a direct violation of my rights and calls into question the legitimacy and security of my student loan records. 

Given these circumstances, I request the following actions : A complete investigation into how my personal and loan-related information was compromised.

Verification and correction of any inaccuracies in my student loan records resulting from this breach.

A hold or suspension on any loan payments until this matter is fully resolved. 

A written statement outlining the actions taken to protect my data and prevent further violations. 

Please provide me with a response within 30 days of receipt of this letter, as required under applicable federal regulations. If necessary, I am prepared to escalate this matter to the XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  and pursue further legal action. 

I appreciate your prompt attention to this serious matter. You may contact me via phone or email to discuss this dispute further. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX

Customer Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Product: Student loan
Complaint Details: My personal and financial information was compromised WITHOUT my authorization. The Family Education Rights and Privacy Act, ( FERPA ), protects the confidentiality of Student Records. This breach is a clear violation of FERPA and your responsibility to safeguard my information. Given the severity of this breach and resulting compromise to my personal and financial information, I request that you immediately cancel and discharge my student loan debt.

Customer Issue: Struggling to repay your loan
Product: Student loan
Complaint Details: My personal and financial information was compromised without authorization. The Family Education Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ) protects the confidentiality of student records. This breach clearly violates FERPA and your responsibility to safeguard my information. Given the severity of this breach and the resulting compromise on my personal and financial information, I request that you immediately discharge my student loan debt.

Customer Issue: Struggling to repay your loan
Product: Student loan
Complaint Details: I am writing to formally file a complaint concerning serious violations related to the management and security of my student loan data. These violations have caused harm to my financial well-being, breached my federally protected privacy rights, and I am requesting that appropriate action be taken to investigate and rectify the matter, including full discharge of my student loan debt and removal of related accounts from my credit reports. 

1. Violation of FERPA ( Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ) : As a borrower of federally guaranteed student loans, I am entitled to protections under FERPA, which mandates the confidentiality and proper use of my education records. My student loan data, which includes personally identifiable information ( PII ), was handled and shared in ways that violated these protections, especially in light of recent disclosures involving third-party servicers and unauthorized data access. These disclosures were made without my knowledge or explicit consent.

2. Violation of the Higher Education Act of XXXX : The Higher Education Act includes provisions to ensure that student loans are administered fairly and that students rights are protected. The failure to secure my sensitive financial and academic information and the inability to provide transparency and accountability from loan servicers constitutes a violation of the intent and letter of this law. 

3. Violation of the Privacy Act of XXXX : This federal law requires that federal agencies and contractors who collect, maintain, and disseminate personal information do so with explicit safeguards and procedures. My XXXX XXXX information, held and shared by the Department of Education and its contracted servicers, has been subject to data breaches and mishandling, constituting gross violations of this Act. I was not given timely notice or meaningful redress following these breaches.

4. Data Breaches and Mismanagement of Private Information : Multiple reports in recent years, including public disclosures by the Department of Education and its servicing partners, have confirmed breaches and unauthorized access of borrower data, affecting millions of student loan borrowers whose private informationincluding Social Security number, loan balances, repayment history, and other sensitive datahas been compromised.

These breaches, combined with the federal violations listed above, have not only endangered my financial privacy but have also negatively impacted my credit report and mental and emotional well-being. I did not consent to my data being exposed, nor was I provided any reasonable opportunity to prevent or mitigate this damage.

Requested Action : In light of these legal violations and the lack of accountability by the Department of Education and its third-party loan servicers, I formally request the following : 1. A full and permanent discharge of all my federal student loan obligations under the authority of borrower defense and/or violation of federal privacy laws.

2. Immediate removal of all student loan accounts from my credit report, as they are tied to improperly handled and compromised information.

3. A full investigation into how my personal information was shared, stored, and breached.

4. A clear explanation of what steps, if any, have been taken by federal authorities and servicers to address these violations and protect borrowers like me.

I respectfully request a prompt review of this complaint and look forward to your response and action. Please contact me via email or phone to confirm receipt and discuss next steps.

Thank you for your time and attention to this serious matter.

This violation is part of the broader context where your personal and financial information was improperly accessed and shared without authorization, violating federal laws designed to protect student records and privacy rights. The breach of FERPA, along with other laws like the Privacy Act of 1974 and the Higher Education Act, underscores the legal violations involved in the mishandling and unauthorized disclosure of your data, which supports your claim for legal dispute and resolution.

data.text:
To Whom It May Concern, I am writing to formally dispute my student loan account due to a violation of the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ) and a breach of my personal data. I recently became aware of unauthorized disclosures of my personally identifiable information ( PII ), which directly impact my loan account and my financial security. 

Under FERPA ( 20 U.S.C. 1232g ; 34 CFR Part 99 ), my educational records and personal data should have been protected from unauthorized access and disclosure. However, I have reason to believe that my information was improperly handled, which may have led to unauthorized transactions, fraudulent activity, or mismanagement of my loan account. 

Additionally, I have been notified of a potential data breach involving my student loan information, which has put my financial identity at risk. This breach is a direct violation of my rights and calls into question the legitimacy and security of my student loan records. 

Given these circumstances, I request the following actions : A complete investigation into how my personal and loan-related information was compromised.

Verification and correction of any inaccuracies in my student loan records resulting from this breach.

A hold or suspension on any loan payments until this matter is fully resolved. 

A written statement outlining the actions taken to protect my data and prevent further violations. 

Please provide me with a response within 30 days of receipt of this letter, as required under applicable federal regulations. If necessary, I am prepared to escalate this matter to the XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  and pursue further legal action. 

I appreciate your prompt attention to this serious matter. You may contact me via phone or email to discuss this dispute further. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX

Product: Student loan

data.context:
XX/XX/year> Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) Complaint Against TransUnion for Failure to Investigate and Accurately Report XXXX Account Violations of the FCRA and Metro 2 Guidelines Dear CFPB Complaint Review XXXX, I am filing this complaint against TransUnion, LLC for their failure to conduct a meaningful and legally compliant investigation into inaccurate credit reporting regarding my XXXX student loan account. Despite repeated contact and documentation, TransUnion has failed to uphold its obligations under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) and industry-standard Metro 2 compliance procedures. 

Background : Over the course of several months, I have submitted multiple disputes and inquiries to TransUnion concerning the accuracy and reporting status of my XXXX account. Despite receiving two vague, non-committal emails from TransUnion stating they are looking into it, there has been no evidence of a proper reinvestigation or corrective action, in direct violation of federal law. 
In addition to contacting TransUnion directly, I have filed formal written complaints and submitted evidence to : The United States Senate and Congressional Representatives The Attorney Generals Office The Consumer Protection Division The U.S. Department of Education, including the Office of General Counsel Federal XXXX Aid ( FSA ) Complaint Center XXXX and TransUnion ( via email and certified mail ) Furthermore, I submitted an application for the Loan Discharge Request ( LDR ) in XX/XX/year>, which has remained in " review '' status without any decision, updates, or correspondence from XXXX. Despite this pending application, my student loans were allowed to default, severely damaging my credit and causing financial and emotional distress. I received no contact by phone, email, or postal mail notifying me of the default status. 
To date, I have submitted a total of three LDR applications and one formal Discharge application seeking relief. None of these have been responded to or processed properly. Meanwhile, TransUnion continues to report inaccurate and incomplete information about this account without verifying its accuracy or properly documenting the ongoing disputes and discharge requests. 

Legal Violations : XXXX. Failure to Conduct a Reasonable Reinvestigation FCRA 611 ( 15 U.S.C. 1681i ) requires CRAs to conduct a reasonable reinvestigation when a consumer disputes information. TransUnion has failed to comply by providing no detailed response or outcome while continuing to report disputed data. 
2. Failure to Maintain Procedural Accuracy FCRA 607 ( b ) ( 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) ) TransUnion is required to maintain procedures to ensure maximum possible accuracy of consumer data. Reporting a defaulted XXXX account despite a pending discharge/LDR application demonstrates procedural failure and negligence. 
3. Metro 2 Compliance Violations Under Metro 2 reporting standards, furnishers and CRAs must correctly reflect dispute codes, deferment/forbearance status, and discharge claims. TransUnion has failed to apply the appropriate codes or suppress reporting while the dispute is ongoing. 
4. Negligent and Willful Noncompliance FCRA 616 & 617 ( 15 U.S.C. 1681n, 1681o ) TransUnion has demonstrated both negligence and willful disregard for the law by continuing to report inaccurate information and failing to correct or investigate the errors, despite ample notice Requested Resolution : Immediate reinvestigation of the XXXX account, with full validation of data and detailed documentation of the source. 

Immediate correction or removal of any XXXX tradeline inaccurately reported in violation of the FCRA and Metro 2 guidelines. 

Cease reporting any default status or negative information while Loan Discharge and LDR applications remain pending. 

An official written response from TransUnion outlining their investigation and confirming full compliance with legal obligations. 

Referral or enforcement action by the CFPB for TransUnions consistent failure to follow the FCRA and industry standards. 

TransUnion 's ongoing disregard for procedural accuracy and consumer rights not only violates federal law but causes serious, real-world harm. I am requesting the CFPB hold them fully accountable for their lack of action and require proper investigation and correction. 
Sincerely, XXXX XXXX

data.context:
Based on the provided complaints, the abolishment of the U.S. Department of Education appears to impact the legality of ongoing student loan reporting and collection practices. Consumer advocates and complainants argue that once the Department of Education was abolished, the student loans that were previously managed or overseen by it became legally void or unverified. 

The impact includes:
- Continued reporting of student loans to credit bureaus that are now considered unverified and legally questionable.
- Ongoing collection efforts by entities like Nelnet despite the loans' legal status being in question following the abolishment.
- Failure by loan servicers to provide evidence of legal ownership, collection rights, or servicing obligations after the Department's dissolution.

Legal violations involved, according to consumer rights advocates, include:
- Violations of the Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA, 15 U.S.C. 1681), particularly regarding the reporting of unverified or questionable debts.
- Violations of the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act (FDCPA, 15 U.S.C. 1692), especially related to unfair and deceptive collection practices and the failure to verify the legitimacy of the debts.

In summary, the abolishment of the Department of Education has led to claims that continued collection and reporting practices are illegal and violate consumer rights, as the debts are now considered legally void or unverified.

data.context:
To Whom It May Concern, I am writing to formally dispute my student loan account due to a violation of the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ) and a breach of my personal data. I recently became aware of unauthorized disclosures of my personally identifiable information ( PII ), which directly impact my loan account and my financial security. 

Under FERPA ( 20 U.S.C. 1232g ; 34 CFR Part 99 ), my educational records and personal data should have been protected from unauthorized access and disclosure. However, I have reason to believe that my information was improperly handled, which may have led to unauthorized transactions, fraudulent activity, or mismanagement of my loan account. 

Additionally, I have been notified of a potential data breach involving my student loan information, which has put my financial identity at risk. This breach is a direct violation of my rights and calls into question the legitimacy and security of my student loan records. 

Given these circumstances, I request the following actions : A complete investigation into how my personal and loan-related information was compromised.

Verification and correction of any inaccuracies in my student loan records resulting from this breach.

A hold or suspension on any loan payments until this matter is fully resolved. 

A written statement outlining the actions taken to protect my data and prevent further violations. 

Please provide me with a response within 30 days of receipt of this letter, as required under applicable federal regulations. If necessary, I am prepared to escalate this matter to the XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  and pursue further legal action. 

I appreciate your prompt attention to this serious matter. You may contact me via phone or email to discuss this dispute further. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX
Customer Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Product: Student loan
Complaint Details: My personal and financial information was compromised WITHOUT my authorization. The Family Education Rights and Privacy Act, ( FERPA ), protects the confidentiality of Student Records. This breach is a clear violation of FERPA and your responsibility to safeguard my information. Given the severity of this breach and resulting compromise to my personal and financial information, I request that you immediately cancel and discharge my student loan debt.
Customer Issue: Struggling to repay your loan
Product: Student loan
Complaint Details: My personal and financial information was compromised without authorization. The Family Education Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ) protects the confidentiality of student records. This breach clearly violates FERPA and your responsibility to safeguard my information. Given the severity of this breach and the resulting compromise on my personal and financial information, I request that you immediately discharge my student loan debt.
Customer Issue: Struggling to repay your loan
Product: Student loan
Complaint Details: I am writing to formally file a complaint concerning serious violations related to the management and security of my student loan data. These violations have caused harm to my financial well-being, breached my federally protected privacy rights, and I am requesting that appropriate action be taken to investigate and rectify the matter, including full discharge of my student loan debt and removal of related accounts from my credit reports. 

1. Violation of FERPA ( Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ) : As a borrower of federally guaranteed student loans, I am entitled to protections under FERPA, which mandates the confidentiality and proper use of my education records. My student loan data, which includes personally identifiable information ( PII ), was handled and shared in ways that violated these protections, especially in light of recent disclosures involving third-party servicers and unauthorized data access. These disclosures were made without my knowledge or explicit consent.

2. Violation of the Higher Education Act of XXXX : The Higher Education Act includes provisions to ensure that student loans are administered fairly and that students rights are protected. The failure to secure my sensitive financial and academic information and the inability to provide transparency and accountability from loan servicers constitutes a violation of the intent and letter of this law. 

3. Violation of the Privacy Act of XXXX : This federal law requires that federal agencies and contractors who collect, maintain, and disseminate personal information do so with explicit safeguards and procedures. My XXXX XXXX information, held and shared by the Department of Education and its contracted servicers, has been subject to data breaches and mishandling, constituting gross violations of this Act. I was not given timely notice or meaningful redress following these breaches.

4. Data Breaches and Mismanagement of Private Information : Multiple reports in recent years, including public disclosures by the Department of Education and its servicing partners, have confirmed breaches and unauthorized access of borrower data, affecting millions of student loan borrowers whose private informationincluding Social Security number, loan balances, repayment history, and other sensitive datahas been compromised.

These breaches, combined with the federal violations listed above, have not only endangered my financial privacy but have also negatively impacted my credit report and mental and emotional well-being. I did not consent to my data being exposed, nor was I provided any reasonable opportunity to prevent or mitigate this damage.

Requested Action : In light of these legal violations and the lack of accountability by the Department of Education and its third-party loan servicers, I formally request the following : 1. A full and permanent discharge of all my federal student loan obligations under the authority of borrower defense and/or violation of federal privacy laws.

2. Immediate removal of all student loan accounts from my credit report, as they are tied to improperly handled and compromised information.

3. A full investigation into how my personal information was shared, stored, and breached.

4. A clear explanation of what steps, if any, have been taken by federal authorities and servicers to address these violations and protect borrowers like me.

I respectfully request a prompt review of this complaint and look forward to your response and action. Please contact me via email or phone to confirm receipt and discuss next steps.

Thank you for your time and attention to this serious matter.

inputs.response:
The violation of the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA) is directly related to the improper use of your student loan report and the breach of your personal information. FERPA is a federal law that mandates the protection and confidentiality of students' educational records and personally identifiable information (PII). When this law is violated, it means that your educational records or PII have been accessed, disclosed, or handled without proper authorization or your consent.

In the context of your complaints, the improper use of your student loan report and the breach of your personal info are considered violations of FERPA because they involve unauthorized disclosures or mishandling of your private educational and financial data. Such breaches can lead to unauthorized transactions, identity theft, or fraud, and undermine your rights to privacy and data security.

Therefore, FERPA violations relate to these issues by indicating that your rights to confidentiality and proper data handling were not upheld, resulting in the exposure and misuse of your personal and loan-related information.
inputs.reference: The violation of FERPA is directly related to the improper use of your student loan report because your student records were disclosed without your consent, which breaches FERPA's strict confidentiality protections. This violation is part of the broader context where your personal and financial information was improperly accessed and shared without authorization, violating federal laws designed to protect student records and privacy rights. The breach of FERPA, along with other laws like the Privacy Act of 1974 and the Higher Education Act, underscores the legal violations involved in the mishandling and unauthorized disclosure of your data, which supports your claim for legal dispute and resolution.

data.context:
I am filing a complaint regarding improper handling of my federal student loans by Nelnet, particularly related to lack of required notification and premature delinquency reporting. 

On XX/XX/XXXX, Nelnet sent me a letter through their portal stating that my federal loans with 0 % interest were paused as of XX/XX/XXXX, through when the payment pause would end, under COVID-19 relief measures and explicitly said : We will notify you in advance of when these relief measures will end. However, I never received any communication from Nelnet notifying me that repayment was restarting, or when my first bill would be due. 

The first indication I received that my loans had entered repayment came in a letter from their portal dated XX/XX/XXXX, stating I was already 15 days past due. I received another notice from their portal on XX/XX/XXXX with the same message, stating that I was again 15 days past due. Then, on XX/XX/XXXX, I received a letter from their portal saying I was 45 days past due. Again, none of these letters came with prior billing statements or warnings about due dates. I never received a statement showing a payment schedule, amount due, or that the CARES Act pause had officially ended. 

In XX/XX/XXXX, my credit score dropped XXXX  XXXX  due to Nelnet reporting my loans as 90120 days past due. These delinquencies were reported without ever having given me proper notice that repayment had resumed, contrary to their own written commitment on XX/XX/XXXX and to Department of Education guidelines. 

I am requesting that the CFPB investigate Nelnet for failure to : -Properly notify me that my loans were exiting forbearance and entering repayment -Provide billing statements or reminders prior to delinquency -Accurately report delinquencies in accordance with the Fair Credit Reporting Act

data.question: How does the violation of the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA) relate to the improper use of my student loan report and the breach of my personal info?
data.answer:
The violation of the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA) is directly related to the improper use of your student loan report and the breach of your personal information. FERPA is a federal law that mandates the protection and confidentiality of students' educational records and personally identifiable information (PII). When this law is violated, it means that your educational records or PII have been accessed, disclosed, or handled without proper authorization or your consent.

In the context of your complaints, the improper use of your student loan report and the breach of your personal info are considered violations of FERPA because they involve unauthorized disclosures or mishandling of your private educational and financial data. Such breaches can lead to unauthorized transactions, identity theft, or fraud, and undermine your rights to privacy and data security.

Therefore, FERPA violations relate to these issues by indicating that your rights to confidentiality and proper data handling were not upheld, resulting in the exposure and misuse of your personal and loan-related information.

data.context: I initially had XXXX as my student loan provider but decided to consolidate my loans and chose AidVantage as the provider. The loans were accepted and dispersed to AidVantage in XX/XX/year> with first payment due on XX/XX/year>. I set up my account and included my banking info to make electronic transfer of funds payments and made the first payment on XX/XX/XXXX. A few days later I received notice that the payment was reversed. I logged into my AidVantage account and checked to make sure my routing and account number were correct. They were, so I attempted to make the payment again on XX/XX/XXXX. They were AidVantage system added both the XX/XX/XXXX payment and the XXXX fifth payment together, doubling the payment amount but I continued to process the payment. Again, a few days later the payment was reversed. I contacted AidVantage through the website and received the response to check to make sure the banking information I entered was correct ( which I had already done ) and to contact my bank to see if they were not accepting the transfer, which ai havent been able to do yet. Im not the average student loan borrower as I am almost XXXX XXXX XXXX, but there has to be a better way to simply make a loan payment. Any assistance appreciated.

data.context:
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Unit XXXX XXXX, GA XXXX United States XXXX XXXX XX/XX/year> Subject : Illegal Student Loan Reporting & Collections Following Department of Education Abolishment Complaint Against : - DEPTEDNELNET ( XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX | ( XXXX ) XXXX ) - XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX To Whom It May Concern, I am filing a formal complaint against DEPTEDNELNET, XXXX XXXX, and XXXX  for continued reporting and collection of student loan debt that is now legally void following the executive order to abolish the U.S. Department of Education.

Complaint Details : 1. Illegal Credit Reporting The credit bureaus continue to report student loans that are now unverified and legally questionable due to the dissolution of the Department of Education.

2. Failure to Verify Legitimacy of Debt The loan servicer ( DEPTEDNELNET ) has failed to provide evidence of legal ownership, collection rights, or servicing obligations in light of the agencys abolishment.

3. Unfair and Deceptive Practices The continued collection of these debts constitutes a violation of my rights under the FCRA ( 15 U.S.C. 1681 ) and FDCPA ( 15 U.S.C. 1692 ). 

I demand an immediate investigation, deletion of these accounts from my credit report, and cessation of any collection efforts by my loan servicer. If this matter is not resolved promptly, I will pursue further legal action. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX

data.context:
Customer Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Product: Student loan
Complaint Details: Several things are going on with Nelnet. 
1. I used to have Great Lakes Borrowers. They were organized and easy to use their website and make payments. Since they're no longer around it went to Nelnet ( not my choice ). I made a payment last month for {$750.00}, when I went to make another payment they added {$430.00} in interest. That is absolutely outrageous to charge me that much, considering I'm not even being sent payments until next year.

2. Nelnet will not let me view any statements of previous payments made to Great Lakes.

3. Nelnet is showing I have FOUR loans to pay back. I should only be paying on XXXX 's and that's it. Same as Great Lakes. Nelnet has Western Govern University ( from XXXX ) and University XXXX XXXX. BOTH have been paid off already! I paid them off years ago, probably XXXX around there. I've tried to research the actual payments through the federal aid website and can't find any payments I've made to them. They're claiming I've paid less than {$2000.00} total. When I've contacted student aid they refuse to help me claiming Nelnet needs to do it when Nelnet is the literal problem.
statements: The consumer is confused about the issuer of the consumer's student loan.
Nelnet states that the issuer of the consumer's student loan is somewhere else.
The consumer has not received clear notice of a change in the issuer of the student loan.
The consumer is concerned about accruing extra interest and late fees without knowing where the consumer's loan is.
The consumer finds the communication from Nelnet insufficient.
The consumer finds the communication from Nelnet frustrating.

data.context: In a letter dated XX/XX/XXXX, I received a letter from my loan servicer telling me that my loan would remain in an administrative forbearance until XX/XX/XXXX and that I didn't need to do anything until XX/XX/XXXX. During the week of XX/XX/XXXX, I happened to log into my servicer 's ( Aidvantage ) website, to confirm the date. The dates it shows that my forbearance ends is XX/XX/XXXX, and not XX/XX/XXXX. I called the servicer and was told that my forbearance ended XX/XX/XXXX. I told the representative that I have 3 different dates that the forbearance would end, and I don't know which date was accurate. The representative proceeded to tell me that the XX/XX/XXXX date was accurate. I explained that I had not received any communication telling me that. I asked her if a letter had been sent to me. She said notifications were set up to go to my phone. I asked her why that wasbthe case ask I had been getting notifications via XXXX postal mail and I hadn't requested that it be changed. I asked that she provide the dates notifications were sent to my phone and to provide me with a copy that was said to have been sent to my phone. She said she didn't see that anything had been sent to me. I explained that had I not called or logged into my online account, I would have never known when the Administrative forbearance would end. As it stands I still don't know when my forbearance will end under the SAVE repayment plan. I'm concerned about my credit being negatively affected for the loan servicer 's failure to provide me with accurate notifications of what is to be expected ; therefore, I am asking you for help in getting this matter resolved.

data.context:
XX/XX/year> Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) Complaint Against TransUnion for Failure to Investigate and Accurately Report XXXX Account Violations of the FCRA and Metro 2 Guidelines Dear CFPB Complaint Review XXXX, I am filing this complaint against TransUnion, LLC for their failure to conduct a meaningful and legally compliant investigation into inaccurate credit reporting regarding my XXXX student loan account. Despite repeated contact and documentation, TransUnion has failed to uphold its obligations under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) and industry-standard Metro 2 compliance procedures. 

Background : Over the course of several months, I have submitted multiple disputes and inquiries to TransUnion concerning the accuracy and reporting status of my XXXX account. Despite receiving two vague, non-committal emails from TransUnion stating they are looking into it, there has been no evidence of a proper reinvestigation or corrective action, in direct violation of federal law. 
In addition to contacting TransUnion directly, I have filed formal written complaints and submitted evidence to : The United States Senate and Congressional Representatives The Attorney Generals Office The Consumer Protection Division The U.S. Department of Education, including the Office of General Counsel Federal XXXX Aid ( FSA ) Complaint Center XXXX and TransUnion ( via email and certified mail ) Furthermore, I submitted an application for the Loan Discharge Request ( LDR ) in XX/XX/year>, which has remained in " review '' status without any decision, updates, or correspondence from XXXX. Despite this pending application, my student loans were allowed to default, severely damaging my credit and causing financial and emotional distress. I received no contact by phone, email, or postal mail notifying me of the default status. 
To date, I have submitted a total of three LDR applications and one formal Discharge application seeking relief. None of these have been responded to or processed properly. Meanwhile, TransUnion continues to report inaccurate and incomplete information about this account without verifying its accuracy or properly documenting the ongoing disputes and discharge requests. 

Legal Violations : XXXX. Failure to Conduct a Reasonable Reinvestigation FCRA 611 ( 15 U.S.C. 1681i ) requires CRAs to conduct a reasonable reinvestigation when a consumer disputes information. TransUnion has failed to comply by providing no detailed response or outcome while continuing to report disputed data. 
2. Failure to Maintain Procedural Accuracy FCRA 607 ( b ) ( 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) ) TransUnion is required to maintain procedures to ensure maximum possible accuracy of consumer data. Reporting a defaulted XXXX account despite a pending discharge/LDR application demonstrates procedural failure and negligence. 
3. Metro 2 Compliance Violations Under Metro 2 reporting standards, furnishers and CRAs must correctly reflect dispute codes, deferment/forbearance status, and discharge claims. TransUnion has failed to apply the appropriate codes or suppress reporting while the dispute is ongoing. 
4. Negligent and Willful Noncompliance FCRA 616 & 617 ( 15 U.S.C. 1681n, 1681o ) TransUnion has demonstrated both negligence and willful disregard for the law by continuing to report inaccurate information and failing to correct or investigate the errors, despite ample notice Requested Resolution : Immediate reinvestigation of the XXXX account, with full validation of data and detailed documentation of the source. 

Immediate correction or removal of any XXXX tradeline inaccurately reported in violation of the FCRA and Metro 2 guidelines. 

Cease reporting any default status or negative information while Loan Discharge and LDR applications remain pending. 

An official written response from TransUnion outlining their investigation and confirming full compliance with legal obligations. 

Referral or enforcement action by the CFPB for TransUnions consistent failure to follow the FCRA and industry standards. 

TransUnion 's ongoing disregard for procedural accuracy and consumer rights not only violates federal law but causes serious, real-world harm. I am requesting the CFPB hold them fully accountable for their lack of action and require proper investigation and correction. 
Sincerely, XXXX XXXX

data.response: The violation of the FCRA by XXXX and XXXX, which involved engaging in sham investigations and failing to conduct proper reinvestigations as required under 15 U.S.C. 1681i, directly relates to the misconduct observed in the handling of the disputed accounts. Specifically, despite the requirement to thoroughly investigate disputed items within 30 days and correct or delete inaccurate information, XXXX and XXXX failed to respond to consumer complaints and did not correct errors, some of which may have been deliberate acts of deception. Additionally, the account transferred to Nelnet was marked by acts of deception, errors, and violations of multiple consumer protection laws, including the FCRA. This pattern of misconduct underscores a systemic failure to adhere to legal obligations under the FCRA, highlighting the importance of proper investigations and accountability to protect consumers from inaccurate reporting and unlawful practices.

data.context:
To Whom It May Concern, I am writing to formally dispute my student loan account due to a violation of the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ) and a breach of my personal data. I recently became aware of unauthorized disclosures of my personally identifiable information ( PII ), which directly impact my loan account and my financial security. 

Under FERPA ( 20 U.S.C. 1232g ; 34 CFR Part 99 ), my educational records and personal data should have been protected from unauthorized access and disclosure. However, I have reason to believe that my information was improperly handled, which may have led to unauthorized transactions, fraudulent activity, or mismanagement of my loan account. 

Additionally, I have been notified of a potential data breach involving my student loan information, which has put my financial identity at risk. This breach is a direct violation of my rights and calls into question the legitimacy and security of my student loan records. 

Given these circumstances, I request the following actions : A complete investigation into how my personal and loan-related information was compromised.

Verification and correction of any inaccuracies in my student loan records resulting from this breach.

A hold or suspension on any loan payments until this matter is fully resolved. 

A written statement outlining the actions taken to protect my data and prevent further violations. 

Please provide me with a response within 30 days of receipt of this letter, as required under applicable federal regulations. If necessary, I am prepared to escalate this matter to the XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  and pursue further legal action. 

I appreciate your prompt attention to this serious matter. You may contact me via phone or email to discuss this dispute further. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX
statements: The violation of FERPA is directly related to the improper use of the student loan report.
Student records were disclosed without consent.
The disclosure of student records without consent breaches FERPA's strict confidentiality protections.
The violation of FERPA is part of a broader context.
Personal and financial information was improperly accessed without authorization.
Personal and financial information was shared without authorization.
The improper access and sharing violate federal laws designed to protect student records and privacy rights.
The breach of FERPA involves legal violations.
Other laws like the Privacy Act of 1974 and the Higher Education Act are also involved in the breach.
The breach includes mishandling and unauthorized disclosure of data.
The legal violations support the claim for legal dispute and resolution.

data.context:
Customer Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Product: Student loan
Complaint Details: Several things are going on with Nelnet. 
1. I used to have Great Lakes Borrowers. They were organized and easy to use their website and make payments. Since they're no longer around it went to Nelnet ( not my choice ). I made a payment last month for {$750.00}, when I went to make another payment they added {$430.00} in interest. That is absolutely outrageous to charge me that much, considering I'm not even being sent payments until next year.

2. Nelnet will not let me view any statements of previous payments made to Great Lakes.

3. Nelnet is showing I have FOUR loans to pay back. I should only be paying on XXXX 's and that's it. Same as Great Lakes. Nelnet has Western Govern University ( from XXXX ) and University XXXX XXXX. BOTH have been paid off already! I paid them off years ago, probably XXXX around there. I've tried to research the actual payments through the federal aid website and can't find any payments I've made to them. They're claiming I've paid less than {$2000.00} total. When I've contacted student aid they refuse to help me claiming Nelnet needs to do it when Nelnet is the literal problem.

data.context:
The violation of the FCRA by XXXX and XXXX, including sham investigations and failure to conduct proper reinvestigations, directly relates to the misconduct and errors made by XXXX and Nelnet in handling the disputed accounts. Specifically, these entities failed to fulfill their legal obligations under the FCRA to conduct reasonable and thorough reinvestigations when consumers disputed the accuracy of their credit information. Instead of properly verifying and correcting the disputed data, they engaged in practices such as sham investigations—meaning investigations that are superficial or intentionally misleading—and neglected to update or correct inaccurate reporting.

This misconduct is evident in the consumer complaints where TransUnion and other furnishers continued to report inaccurate account statuses, such as defaulted loans despite evidence of settlement or discharge, and failed to document ongoing disputes. For example, Nelnet's refusal to settle accounts despite receipt of negotiable instruments, and TransUnion’s continued reporting of disputed accounts without proper investigation, exemplify these failures.

The implications for consumer protection under the FCRA are significant. These violations undermine consumers' rights to accurate credit reporting and fair dispute resolution. When furnishers and credit reporting agencies conduct sham investigations or ignore proper procedures, consumers are left with inaccurate information that can harm their credit scores, financial standing, and ability to access credit or benefits. Such misconduct also erodes trust in the credit reporting system and highlights the need for strict enforcement of the FCRA to ensure that entities conduct genuine, comprehensive investigations and uphold accuracy and transparency in credit reporting.

The violation involved engaging in sham investigations.
The violation involved failing to conduct proper reinvestigations as required under 15 U.S.C. 1681i.

There is a requirement to thoroughly investigate disputed items within 30 days.
There is a requirement to correct or delete inaccurate information.
XXXX and XXXX failed to respond to consumer complaints.
XXXX and XXXX did not correct errors.
Some of the errors may have been deliberate acts of deception.
The account transferred to Nelnet was marked by acts of deception.
The account transferred to Nelnet was marked by errors.
The account transferred to Nelnet violated multiple consumer protection laws.
The account transferred to Nelnet violated the FCRA.
This pattern of misconduct shows a systemic failure to adhere to legal obligations under the FCRA.
Proper investigations and accountability are important to protect consumers from inaccurate reporting.
Proper investigations and accountability are important to protect consumers from unlawful practices.

data.context:
I am submitting this complaint regarding unauthorized interest accrual on my XXXX XXXX XXXX  enrolled in the SAVE ( Saving on a XXXX XXXX ) plan. Despite the Department of Education 's explicit guidance that loans under the SAVE plan should not accrue interest during the administrative forbearance period, Aidvantage has allowed interest to accrue on my account, resulting in an increase in my loan balance. 

Here is a summary of the issue and timeline : Department of Education Guidance : The Department of Education mandated that all borrowers enrolled in the SAVE plan be placed into an interest-free administrative forbearance beginning XX/XX/XXXX, due to ongoing legal challenges. During this period, no interest was supposed to accrue on loans. 

Aidvantage 's Actions : Aidvantage stated in their letter dated XX/XX/XXXX, that my loans were in a general forbearance with no interest accruing from XX/XX/XXXX, through XX/XX/XXXX. 

However, they claim that when I submitted a new Income-Driven Repayment ( IDR ) application on XX/XX/XXXX, my loans were moved into a " processing forbearance '' for up to 60 days. During this processing forbearance, Aidvantage allowed interest to accrue on my loans starting XX/XX/XXXX, despite my enrollment in the SAVE plan. 

When my application was not processed within the 60-day window, Aidvantage states that my account was moved back into a general forbearance effective XX/XX/XXXX, during which interest was set to 0 %. 

Impact : My loan balance increased from {$72000.00} ( as of XX/XX/XXXX ) to {$73000.00} as of nowa difference of {$1300.00} in unauthorized accrued interest. 

This interest accrual violates the Department of Educations directive that loans under the SAVE plan should not accrue interest during administrative forbearance. 

Attempts to Resolve : I have made over a dozen phone calls to Aidvantage since XX/XX/XXXX, totaling more than 12 hours of time spent trying to resolve this issue. 

During each call, I was promised a supervisor callback within 24-48 business hours, but no supervisor has ever followed up with me. 

I escalated this issue to the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB Complaint # XXXX ), but Aidvantage falsely reported to the CFPB that the issue was resolved when it was not. 

Why This Is a Problem : Aidvantages actions are inconsistent with federal regulations and Department of Education mandates regarding the SAVE plan. The Department explicitly stated that borrowers enrolled in SAVE should not accrue interest during administrative forbearance. By allowing interest to accrue during the processing forbearance period ( XX/XX/XXXX XX/XX/XXXX ), Aidvantage has violated these directives. 

Additionally : Their explanation in their XX/XX/XXXX letter does not align with federal guidance. 

Their failure to follow through on promised callbacks and their false reporting to the CFPB demonstrate systemic issues in their handling of borrower complaints.

What I Am Requesting : Immediate removal of the {$1300.00} in unauthorized accrued interest from my account. 

Restoration of my loan balance to {$72000.00} as it was in XX/XX/XXXX. 

Written confirmation from Aidvantage detailing these corrections and assurances that no further interest will accrue while my account remains under administrative forbearance as mandated by the Department of Education.

Accountability for Aidvantages false reporting to the CFPB and failure to provide adequate customer service. 

A formal investigation into whether Aidvantage is systematically violating Department of Education mandates regarding SAVE plan borrowers.

This issue has caused significant stress and wasted time due to Aidvantages noncompliance and lack of accountability. I request immediate action from both Aidvantage and federal authorities to resolve this matter fairly and ensure compliance with federal regulations moving forward. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX, XXXX

Aidvantage's failure resulted in an incorrect payment amount despite proper documentation.
Aidvantage also failed to confirm the autopay setup.

These issues demonstrate the critical need for Aidvantage to ensure accurate processing of applications.

Accurate processing and clear communication by Aidvantage can prevent unjust billing.

data.context: In a letter dated XX/XX/XXXX, I received a letter from my loan servicer telling me that my loan would remain in an administrative forbearance until XX/XX/XXXX and that I didn't need to do anything until XX/XX/XXXX. During the week of XX/XX/XXXX, I happened to log into my servicer 's ( Aidvantage ) website, to confirm the date. The dates it shows that my forbearance ends is XX/XX/XXXX, and not XX/XX/XXXX. I called the servicer and was told that my forbearance ended XX/XX/XXXX. I told the representative that I have 3 different dates that the forbearance would end, and I don't know which date was accurate. The representative proceeded to tell me that the XX/XX/XXXX date was accurate. I explained that I had not received any communication telling me that. I asked her if a letter had been sent to me. She said notifications were set up to go to my phone. I asked her why that wasbthe case ask I had been getting notifications via XXXX postal mail and I hadn't requested that it be changed. I asked that she provide the dates notifications were sent to my phone and to provide me with a copy that was said to have been sent to my phone. She said she didn't see that anything had been sent to me. I explained that had I not called or logged into my online account, I would have never known when the Administrative forbearance would end. As it stands I still don't know when my forbearance will end under the SAVE repayment plan. I'm concerned about my credit being negatively affected for the loan servicer 's failure to provide me with accurate notifications of what is to be expected ; therefore, I am asking you for help in getting this matter resolved.

data.context:
The violation of the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA) is directly related to the improper use of your student loan report and the breach of your personal information. FERPA is a federal law that mandates the protection and confidentiality of students' educational records and personally identifiable information (PII). When this law is violated, it means that your educational records or PII have been accessed, disclosed, or handled without proper authorization or your consent.

In the context of your complaints, the improper use of your student loan report and the breach of your personal info are considered violations of FERPA because they involve unauthorized disclosures or mishandling of your private educational and financial data. Such breaches can lead to unauthorized transactions, identity theft, or fraud, and undermine your rights to privacy and data security.

Therefore, FERPA violations relate to these issues by indicating that your rights to confidentiality and proper data handling were not upheld, resulting in the exposure and misuse of your personal and loan-related information.
statements: FERPA was violated.
The violation of FERPA is related to the improper use of your student loan report.
Your student records were disclosed without your consent.
Disclosing your student records without your consent breaches FERPA's strict confidentiality protections.
This violation is part of a broader context.
Your personal and financial information was improperly accessed without authorization.
Your personal and financial information was shared without authorization.
Federal laws exist to protect student records and privacy rights.
The unauthorized access and sharing violated federal laws designed to protect student records and privacy rights.
FERPA was breached.
Other laws like the Privacy Act of 1974 and the Higher Education Act were also breached.
The breach of these laws shows legal violations in mishandling and unauthorized disclosure of your data.
These legal violations support your claim for legal dispute and resolution.

data.context:
To Whom It May Concern, I am writing to formally dispute my student loan account due to a violation of the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ( FERPA ) and a breach of my personal data. I recently became aware of unauthorized disclosures of my personally identifiable information ( PII ), which directly impact my loan account and my financial security. 

Under FERPA ( 20 U.S.C. 1232g ; 34 CFR Part 99 ), my educational records and personal data should have been protected from unauthorized access and disclosure. However, I have reason to believe that my information was improperly handled, which may have led to unauthorized transactions, fraudulent activity, or mismanagement of my loan account. 

Additionally, I have been notified of a potential data breach involving my student loan information, which has put my financial identity at risk. This breach is a direct violation of my rights and calls into question the legitimacy and security of my student loan records. 

Given these circumstances, I request the following actions : A complete investigation into how my personal and loan-related information was compromised.

Verification and correction of any inaccuracies in my student loan records resulting from this breach.

A hold or suspension on any loan payments until this matter is fully resolved. 

A written statement outlining the actions taken to protect my data and prevent further violations. 

Please provide me with a response within 30 days of receipt of this letter, as required under applicable federal regulations. If necessary, I am prepared to escalate this matter to the XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  and pursue further legal action. 

I appreciate your prompt attention to this serious matter. You may contact me via phone or email to discuss this dispute further. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX

data.context:
I am submitting this complaint regarding unauthorized interest accrual on my XXXX XXXX XXXX  enrolled in the SAVE ( Saving on a XXXX XXXX ) plan. Despite the Department of Education 's explicit guidance that loans under the SAVE plan should not accrue interest during the administrative forbearance period, Aidvantage has allowed interest to accrue on my account, resulting in an increase in my loan balance. 

Here is a summary of the issue and timeline : Department of Education Guidance : The Department of Education mandated that all borrowers enrolled in the SAVE plan be placed into an interest-free administrative forbearance beginning XX/XX/XXXX, due to ongoing legal challenges. During this period, no interest was supposed to accrue on loans. 

Aidvantage 's Actions : Aidvantage stated in their letter dated XX/XX/XXXX, that my loans were in a general forbearance with no interest accruing from XX/XX/XXXX, through XX/XX/XXXX. 

However, they claim that when I submitted a new Income-Driven Repayment ( IDR ) application on XX/XX/XXXX, my loans were moved into a " processing forbearance '' for up to 60 days. During this processing forbearance, Aidvantage allowed interest to accrue on my loans starting XX/XX/XXXX, despite my enrollment in the SAVE plan. 

When my application was not processed within the 60-day window, Aidvantage states that my account was moved back into a general forbearance effective XX/XX/XXXX, during which interest was set to 0 %. 

Impact : My loan balance increased from {$72000.00} ( as of XX/XX/XXXX ) to {$73000.00} as of nowa difference of {$1300.00} in unauthorized accrued interest. 

This interest accrual violates the Department of Educations directive that loans under the SAVE plan should not accrue interest during administrative forbearance. 

Attempts to Resolve : I have made over a dozen phone calls to Aidvantage since XX/XX/XXXX, totaling more than 12 hours of time spent trying to resolve this issue. 

During each call, I was promised a supervisor callback within 24-48 business hours, but no supervisor has ever followed up with me. 

I escalated this issue to the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB Complaint # XXXX ), but Aidvantage falsely reported to the CFPB that the issue was resolved when it was not. 

Why This Is a Problem : Aidvantages actions are inconsistent with federal regulations and Department of Education mandates regarding the SAVE plan. The Department explicitly stated that borrowers enrolled in SAVE should not accrue interest during administrative forbearance. By allowing interest to accrue during the processing forbearance period ( XX/XX/XXXX XX/XX/XXXX ), Aidvantage has violated these directives. 

Additionally : Their explanation in their XX/XX/XXXX letter does not align with federal guidance. 

Their failure to follow through on promised callbacks and their false reporting to the CFPB demonstrate systemic issues in their handling of borrower complaints.

What I Am Requesting : Immediate removal of the {$1300.00} in unauthorized accrued interest from my account. 

Restoration of my loan balance to {$72000.00} as it was in XX/XX/XXXX. 

Written confirmation from Aidvantage detailing these corrections and assurances that no further interest will accrue while my account remains under administrative forbearance as mandated by the Department of Education.

Accountability for Aidvantages false reporting to the CFPB and failure to provide adequate customer service. 

A formal investigation into whether Aidvantage is systematically violating Department of Education mandates regarding SAVE plan borrowers.

This issue has caused significant stress and wasted time due to Aidvantages noncompliance and lack of accountability. I request immediate action from both Aidvantage and federal authorities to resolve this matter fairly and ensure compliance with federal regulations moving forward. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX, XXXX

data.context:
Subject : Illegal Student Loan Reporting & Collections Following Department of Education Abolishment To Whom It May Concern : I am filing a former complaint against AidVantage, XXXX XXXX and XXXX for continued reporting and collection of student loan debt that is now legally void following the executive order to abolish the U.S. Department of Education.

Complaint Details : 1. Illegal Credit Reporting The credit bureaus continue to report student loans that are now unverified and legally questionable due to the dissolution of the Department of Education. 
2. Failure to Verify Legitimacy of Debt The loan servicer has failed to provide evidence of legal ownership, collection rights, or servicing obligations in light of the agencys abolishment.

3. Unfair and Deceptive Practices The continued collection of these debts constitutes a violation of my rights under the FCRA ( 15 U.S.C. 1681 ) and FDCPA ( 15 U.S.C. 1692 ).

I demand an immediate investigation, deletion of these accounts from my credit report, and cessation of any collection efforts by my loan servicer. If this matter is not resolved promptly, I will pursue further legal action. 

XXXX DL Consolidated - Subsidized {$22000.00} 4.375 % XX/XX/year> XXXX DL Consolidated - Unsubsidized {$30000.00} 4.375 % XX/XX/year> XXXX Direct Loan - Unsubsidized {$21000.00} 7.050 % XX/XX/year> XXXX Direct Loan - Unsubsidized {$13000.00} 8.080 %

Customer Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Product: Student loan
Complaint Details: I am pursuing Public Service Loan Forgiveness and have made XXXX qualifying payments, including during the pandemic forbearance period which the Department of Education stated would count toward PSLF. I worked full-time for qualifying employers from XXXX and submitted employment certifications through the PSLF Help Tool. 

In XXXX, I was told I qualified for forgiveness. However, as of XX/XX/XXXX, my loans have not been discharged. I also discovered an IDR application was submitted on my behalf without consent, which may have affected my PSLF count. I contacted my servicer ( Edfinancial ) but was told conflicting information about my forgiveness status and the impact of the forbearance months. I also submitted a complaint to the Department of Education, but it was closed without resolution or clear explanation.

I am requesting a review of my PSLF eligibility, confirmation that the pandemic forbearance months were properly credited, and immediate processing of the forgiveness I qualified for in XXXX.
statements: The customer issue involves dealing with the lender or servicer.
The product involved is a student loan.
The federal student loan COVID-19 forbearance program ended in XX/XX/XXXX.

The new payment amount is effective starting with the XX/XX/XXXX payment.
The new payment amount will nearly double the payment from $180.00 per month to $360.00 per month.
The customer is fortunate that the current financial position allows handling the increased payment amount.
There are likely many borrowers who are not in the same financial position.
The re-amortization should have occurred once the forbearance ended.
The re-amortization would reduce the impact to borrowers.

data.context:
Subject : Illegal Student Loan Reporting & Collections Following Department of Education Abolishment To Whom It May Concern : I am filing a former complaint against AidVantage, XXXX XXXX and XXXX for continued reporting and collection of student loan debt that is now legally void following the executive order to abolish the U.S. Department of Education.

Complaint Details : 1. Illegal Credit Reporting The credit bureaus continue to report student loans that are now unverified and legally questionable due to the dissolution of the Department of Education. 
2. Failure to Verify Legitimacy of Debt The loan servicer has failed to provide evidence of legal ownership, collection rights, or servicing obligations in light of the agencys abolishment.

3. Unfair and Deceptive Practices The continued collection of these debts constitutes a violation of my rights under the FCRA ( 15 U.S.C. 1681 ) and FDCPA ( 15 U.S.C. 1692 ).

I demand an immediate investigation, deletion of these accounts from my credit report, and cessation of any collection efforts by my loan servicer. If this matter is not resolved promptly, I will pursue further legal action. 

XXXX DL Consolidated - Subsidized {$22000.00} 4.375 % XX/XX/year> XXXX DL Consolidated - Unsubsidized {$30000.00} 4.375 % XX/XX/year> XXXX Direct Loan - Unsubsidized {$21000.00} 7.050 % XX/XX/year> XXXX Direct Loan - Unsubsidized {$13000.00} 8.080 %

This account was transferred to Nelnet ( NNI ) from XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ; who had engaged in acts of deception and made numerous errors on the account, as well as having broken numerous consumer protection laws, including the FDCPA, FCRA, TCPA, Indiana Senior Consumer Protection Act, Indiana Deceptive Consumers Sales Act. This occurred in XXXX and XXXX. We then sent letters to Nelnet by Certified Mail ( CM ) several times in XXXX and XXXX, detailing the serious misconduct by XXXX. 

Despite signing for the CM and acknowledging receipt of the written complaint and violations of law, XXXX never responded to the CM, nor provided any answers to the questions raised in the CM. XXXX never corrected any of the errors- some of which may have been not just errors but deliberate acts of covering-up acts of deception. XXXX then began a series of doing many of the same violations of law. 

XXXX seems to have a Compliance Problem.

data.context:
XX/XX/year> Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) Complaint Against TransUnion for Failure to Investigate and Accurately Report XXXX Account Violations of the FCRA and XXXX XXXX Guidelines Dear CFPB Complaint Review XXXX, I am filing this complaint against TransUnion, LLC for their failure to conduct a meaningful and legally compliant investigation into inaccurate credit reporting regarding my XXXX student loan account. Despite repeated contact and documentation, TransUnion has failed to uphold its obligations under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) and industry-standard Metro XXXX compliance procedures. 
Background : Over the course of several months, I have submitted multiple disputes and inquiries to TransUnion concerning the accuracy and reporting status of my XXXX account. Despite receiving XXXX vague, non-committal emails from TransUnion stating they are looking into it, there has been no evidence of a proper reinvestigation or corrective action, in direct violation of federal law. 
In addition to contacting TransUnion directly, I have filed formal written complaints and submitted evidence to : The United States Senate and Congressional Representatives The Attorney Generals Office The Consumer Protection Division The U.S. Department of Education, including the Office of General Counsel Federal Student Aid ( FSA ) Complaint Center XXXX and TransUnion ( via email and certified mail ) Furthermore, I submitted an application for the Loan Discharge Request ( XXXX ) in XX/XX/year>, which has remained in " review '' status without any decision, updates, or correspondence from XXXX. Despite this pending application, my student loans were allowed to default, severely damaging my credit and causing financial and emotional distress. I received no contact by phone, email, or postal mail notifying me of the default status. 
To date, I have submitted a total of XXXX XXXX applications and XXXX formal Discharge application seeking relief. None of these have been responded to or processed properly. Meanwhile, TransUnion continues to report inaccurate and incomplete information about this account without verifying its accuracy or properly documenting the ongoing disputes and discharge requests. 

Legal Violations : XXXX. Failure to Conduct a Reasonable Reinvestigation FCRA 611 ( 15 U.S.C. 1681i ) requires CRAs to conduct a reasonable reinvestigation when a consumer disputes information. TransUnion has failed to comply by providing no detailed response or outcome while continuing to report disputed data. 
XXXX. Failure to Maintain Procedural Accuracy FCRA 607 ( b ) ( 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) ) TransUnion is required to maintain procedures to ensure maximum possible accuracy of consumer data. Reporting a defaulted XXXX account despite a pending discharge/LDR application demonstrates procedural failure and negligence. 
XXXX. Metro 2 Compliance Violations Under Metro 2 reporting standards, furnishers and CRAs must correctly reflect dispute codes, deferment/forbearance status, and discharge claims. TransUnion has failed to apply the appropriate codes or suppress reporting while the dispute is ongoing. 
XXXX. Negligent and Willful Noncompliance FCRA 616 & 617 ( 15 U.S.C. 1681n, 1681o ) TransUnion has demonstrated both negligence and willful disregard for the law by continuing to report inaccurate information and failing to correct or investigate the errors, despite ample notice Requested Resolution : Immediate reinvestigation of the XXXX account, with full validation of data and detailed documentation of the source. 

Immediate correction or removal of any XXXX tradeline inaccurately reported in violation of the FCRA and XXXX XXXX guidelines. 

Cease reporting any default status or negative information while XXXX XXXX and XXXX applications remain pending. 

An official written response from TransUnion outlining their investigation and confirming full compliance with legal obligations. 

Referral or enforcement action by the CFPB for TransUnions consistent failure to follow the FCRA and industry standards. 

TransUnion 's ongoing disregard for procedural accuracy and consumer rights not only violates federal law but causes serious, real-world harm. I am requesting the CFPB hold them fully accountable for their lack of action and require proper investigation and correction. 
Sincerely, XXXX XXXX

data.context:
This account was transferred to Nelnet ( NNI ) from XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ; who had engaged in acts of deception and made numerous errors on the account, as well as having broken numerous consumer protection laws, including the FDCPA, FCRA, TCPA, Indiana Senior Consumer Protection Act, Indiana Deceptive Consumers Sales Act. This occurred in XXXX and XXXX. We then sent letters to Nelnet by Certified Mail ( CM ) several times in XXXX and XXXX, detailing the serious misconduct by XXXX. 

Despite signing for the CM and acknowledging receipt of the written complaint and violations of law, XXXX never responded to the CM, nor provided any answers to the questions raised in the CM. XXXX never corrected any of the errors- some of which may have been not just errors but deliberate acts of covering-up acts of deception. XXXX then began a series of doing many of the same violations of law. 

XXXX seems to have a Compliance Problem.
